TopicTitle: [Request] Could someone suppy me with a .MU of this simple shape?

Articles.Content: I struggled for about half a day with various modeling software, but I can't seem to get the .mu exporter working in blender. So If someone would be able/willing to create this shape and supply me with a .mu, I will forever be in your debt. It doesn't need textures or any thing, the model alone will do just fine. I'm planning to use it as a Chroma-key backdrop to fake moon landings on for fun and profit.

I struggled for about half a day with various modeling software, but I can't seem to get the .mu exporter working in blender. I'm planning to use it as a Chroma-key backdrop to fake moon landings on for fun and profit. http://i.imgur.com/04yo8rZ.png

Be happy to do it for ya (after the help you've already given me.)

Just making sure i understand your diagram correctly. It seems like basically a stage ( sans top?)

- - - Updated - - -

This wouldn't have anything to do with /r/KerbalSpaceProgram's faking landings on Kerbin challenge, would it?

I was not aware of that challenge, but it I'm definitely interested. I was toying with the idea of creating an Kerbal konstructs film-set with green screens and fake mun/duna terrain sets.

If you're using the model as a chroma-key backdrop, I would strongly recommend applying an emissive texture in blue or green - a regular diffuse texture would cause the model to cast shadows on itself, resulting in an uneven chroma key effect.

If you're using the model as a chroma-key backdrop, I would strongly recommend applying an emissive texture in blue or green - a regular diffuse texture would cause the model to cast shadows on itself, resulting in an uneven chroma key effect.
Will do, thanks for the the tip! I'm going for magenta as a key colour I think, because it's the most distant point in gamut from the skin colour of kerbals.

Magneta sounds perfectly reasonable.

Will do, thanks for the the tip! I'm going for magenta as a key colour I think, because it's the most distant point in gamut from the skin colour of kerbals.

That's a pretty good idea. I used to use pure magenta for matting sprites in some old shareware games, since it was the most distant from pretty much everything any of the images would legitimately have.
